Graphical abstract Cu9-Al x or Cu9-Al x -M y (M=Mg, Ca, Ba or Sr) catalysts were prepared by a deposition-precipitation method, characterized by means of H2-TPR, XRD and N2 sorption, and applied for hydrogenation of ethyl acetate to ethanol in a fixed-bed reactor. The molar ratio of Cu/Al or Cu/Al/M and the reaction parameters were investigated thoroughly. As a result, the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst with higher specific surface area, lower initial reduction temperature and better metal dispersion furnished 97.8% ethyl acetate conversion with 98% selectivity to ethanol under optimal reaction conditions. Moreover, the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst also showed good lifetime and neither the activity nor selectivity decreased during 210h test. Based on the characterization of the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst, the optimal Cu+/Cu0 proportion played a key role in determining the superior performance. Keywords Catalytic hydrogenation Cu-Al x -M y catalyst Ethyl acetate Ethanol 1 Introduction Ethanol has a wide range of applications. It can be widely used as disinfectant in medicine, called as alcohol. Because of its active property, ethanol is also widely used as one of the most important raw materials for organic syntheses, such as ethyl ether, acetic acid, aldehyde, etc. [1,2]. Particularly, as a new clean gasoline alternative, fuel ethanol is currently one kind of the renewable-energy in the world. Nowadays, with rapid development of industry, the gap between energy supply and demand is increasingly enlarged. Many countries began to pay attention to production of fuel ethanol. Recently, there is an increasing interest in using ethanol-gasoline as an alternative fuel, because oxygen-containing ethanol makes the combustion of ethanol is more sufficient, which can reduce the amount of carbon monoxide and hydrocarbons in automobile exhaust [3–6]. As for production of ethanol, it is mainly produced from grain fermentation in China at this stage; however, the production is greatly influenced by the grain price. Moreover, only excess grain can be applied to fermentation to produce ethanol. Therefore, an energy-saving and environmentally benign method for synthesis of ethanol is still needed. Meanwhile, China has become one of the largest countries in production of acetic acid, and unfortunately, the acetic acid production greatly surpasses the market demand. Therefore, it is urgent to explore a new conversion route for acetic acid. With regards of this aspect, converting acetic acid to ethanol via direct or indirect hydrogenation is becoming a hot spot of research. Direct hydrogenation of acetic acid hydrogenation to ethanol usually needs noble metal catalysts such as Pd or Pt-based catalyst [7–11]. However, noble metal resources are scarce and costly, which prevents a large-scale industrialization. In addition, severe corrosion of acetic acid makes the industrialization of direct hydrogenation of acetic acid to ethanol need huge investment. Indirect hydrogenation of acetic acid, that is, esterification of acetic acid to acetates firstly and then hydrogenation of acetates to the corresponding alcohols can effectively avoid the above problems using copper-based catalysts. For ester hydrogenolysis, copper-based catalysts are well known to exhibit high activities, because they allow selective cleavage of CO and are relatively inactive in CC bond cleavage [12–20]. Of particular note is that the cost of Cu-containing catalysts is thus dramatically reduced. Nevertheless, there are still a few problems to be solved for Cu-based catalysts. For instance, Zhu et al. investigated the Cu-Zn/SiO2 catalyst and proposed a pathway for ethyl acetate hydrogenation to ethanol, but the conversion only reached 81.6% with the selectivity to ethanol of 93.8% [21]. Luo et al. investigated commercial Cu-Cr catalysts for ethyl acetate hydrogenation to ethanol in a fixed-bed reactor or in a continuous stirring tank reactor. The Cu-Cr catalyst maintains a constant conversion initially, but there is an obvious decline thereafter [22]. In a word, the short lifetime of the Cu-based catalyst needs to be prolonged and the activity of the Cu-based catalyst needs to be further improved. Herein, we modify the Cu-based catalyst with Al and then with the alkaline earth metal component to achieve higher performance for the hydrogenation of ethyl acetate to ethanol. Different molar ratios of Cu/Al for Cu9-Al x were investigated. Under the optimal Cu/Al molar ratio of 9:0.5, the conversion of ethyl acetate reached 68.8% with the selectivity to ethanol over 98%. After addition of the alkaline earth metal like Mg to Cu9-Al0.5, the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst showed greatly enhanced activity, selectivity and stability. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The Cu9-Al x or Cu9-Al x -M y catalysts were prepared by a deposition-precipitation method. A mixed aqueous solution containing Cu(NO3)2∙3H2O and Al(NO3)2∙9H2O with/without Mg(NO3)2∙6H2O (or Ca(NO3)2 or Ba(NO3)2 or Sr(NO3)2) (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co, Ltd.) with different molar ratios of 9/x or 9/x/y was made and stirred for about 30min at room temperature. Then, the mixed solution was heated to 80°C. After that, an aqueous solution of 10wt.% Na2CO3 was added to keep the solution pH value of about 8, and the mixture was stirred at 80°C for additional 8h. Finally, the resultant precipitate was recovered by filtration, washed with deionized water, and dried at 100°C for 8h. After calcination at 350°C in air for 2h, the samples were shaped and then sieved to 20–40 meshes for use. For comparison, the catalyst precursor was also calcined at other temperatures in air before reduced in hydrogen. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The ex-situ XRD patterns of samples were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer using Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.5406Å) with a scanning angle (2θ) range of 5–80°, a scanning speed of 60°/min with a voltage of 40kV, and a current of 40mA. The samples were reduced in flowing hydrogen at 350°C for 2h prior to taking XRD patterns, and no protective step was taken to avoid surface re-oxidation. N2 physisorption of the reduced samples was conducted on a Quantachrome Autosorb-1 system at liquid nitrogen temperature (−196°C) after the samples were outgassed at 300°C under vacuum for 3h to remove physically adsorbed species. The specific surface areas were calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation. Total pore volumes were evaluated at relative pressures (P/P0) close to unity. Pore size distributions were estimated by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method according to the desorption branch of the isotherms. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were recorded with an FEI Tecnai G2-TF30 electron microscope operated at an accelerating voltage of 300kV. The H2-TPR profiles were conducted with a Quantachrome CHEMBET-3000 apparatus. During the experiments, each sample (100mg) was outgassed under flowing He (99.999%, 30ml/min) at 200°C for 30min and then cooled to ambient temperature. The H2-TPR profiles were obtained with a 10% H2/N2 flow (30ml/min). The temperature was increased from 30°C to 600°C with a ramping rate of 10°C/min. To correlate with the reaction results, the X-ray photoelectron spectrum (XPS) of sample was recorded with ESCALAB 250 spectrometer after the sample was pretreated in situ in flowing hydrogen at 350°C for 2h. The Al Kα X-ray radiation source (hv =1486.6eV) was operated at 14kV and 20mA. The carbonaceous C 1s line (284.6eV) was used as the reference to calibrate the binding energies (BEs). The spectra shown in the figures have been corrected by subtraction of a Shirley background. Spectral fitting and peak integration was done using the XPSPEAK software. 2.3 Catalytic test The catalytic test was performed using a fixed-bed reactor. Typically, 1.0g of catalyst (20–40 meshes) was loaded into a stainless steel tubular reactor (with 55cm length and i.d. of 12mm) with a thermocouple inserted into the catalyst bed for control of the actual temperature. The catalyst was reduced under hydrogen atmosphere (99.999% purity, 2MPa, 60ml/min) at 350°C for 2h firstly. Then, the hydrogen flow rate was modulated using a mass flow controller and the pressure was controlled by a regulator valve. The hydrogenation of ethyl acetate began after ethyl acetate was pumped to the catalyst bed at a tunable flow rate. Normally, 0.02ml/min of ethyl acetate flow rate, 60ml/min of hydrogen flow rate, 2MPa of hydrogen pressure and hydrogenation at 250°C were applied for a standard catalytic test. For optimization of reaction parameters, effects of ethyl acetate flow rate, hydrogen flow rate, hydrogen pressure and reaction temperatures on the hydrogenation of ethyl acetate were also investigated separately. The products were collected every 2h and the second sample collected after 4h time of stream was analyzed offline using GC with an FID (TECHCOMP GC-7900 Plus, Tianmei Ltd. Co.) to compare the catalytic performance of different catalysts. The response factor of each component was calculated using standard samples and was used to calculate the conversion and selectivity. For catalyst stability test, the reaction was performed continuously and the sample was collected every 2 or 3h. The error bar for the catalytic testing is ±5% based on GC analysis. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance of Cu9-Al x catalysts Firstly, we investigated the binary Cu9-Al x catalysts for the hydrogenation of ethyl acetate to ethanol. It is worth noting that the selectivity to ethanol is over 98% regardless of the conversion of ethyl acetate. Trace amount of ethylene and COx derived from decomposition of ethyl acetate were also detected in the product. Nevertheless, the conversion of ethyl acetate was significantly affected by the molar ratio of Cu/Al. As shown in Fig. 1 , the conversion of ethyl acetate increased dramatically with Al amount firstly and reached a maximum when x was equal to 0.5. When the Al amount x was further increased, the conversion of ethyl acetate was decreased instead. As a result, the highest conversion of 68.8% was obtained with the Cu9-Al0.5 catalyst. In order to explain this phenomenon, the reduced Cu9-Al x catalysts were characterized using XRD. As can be seen from Fig. 2 , the bare Cu catalyst showed three obvious diffraction peaks at 2θ of 43.3°, 50.4° and 74.1°, assignable to (111), (200) and (220) planes of Cu. Compared with the bare Cu catalyst, the Cu9-Al0.5 catalyst showed broader diffraction peak of Cu(111) plane, indicating that the Cu particles were more uniformly and highly dispersed. Moreover, trace amount of CuO species were also detected for the Cu9-Al0.5 catalyst, which might be originated from unreduced CuO or from re-oxidation of Cu particles when contacted air after reduction. Because no protective step was taken to avoid surface oxidation after reduction of samples, we would not discuss the CuO diffraction anymore in the following studies and just concentrated on the diffraction of Cu(111) plane. With increase of x value to 1.0, the Cu diffractions became stronger. However, if x value was further increased to 1.5, the diffraction peaks assignable to Cu species were negligible for the Cu9-Al1.5 catalyst. This demonstrates that addition of Al with small amount is profoundly beneficial for dispersion of Cu particles. According to Scherrer equation, the average Cu crystallite size was about 26nm of Cu9-Al0, while it was about 20nm for Cu9-Al0.5. However, too much Al would cause aggregation of Cu particles again, and the average Cu crystallite size was about 28nm of Cu9-Al1. Therefore, Cu9-Al0.5 was selected for the following studies. 3.2 Catalytic performance of Cu9-Al0.5-My catalysts In order to further improve the catalytic activity, different alkaline-earth metal was doped as the third component, such as Mg, Ca, Ba or Sr. As already displayed in Fig. 3 , the catalytic performance of Cu9-Al0.5-M y was influenced greatly by the alkaline-earth metal. To our delight, when Mg was doped, the conversion of ethyl acetate obtained with the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg y catalysts was increased with Mg amount initially and reached a maximum at the Cu/Al/Mg molar ratio of 9/0.5/1.5. If the Mg amount was further increased (y> 1.5), the catalytic performance of Cu9-Al0.5-Mg y catalyst was dramatically decreased. As a result, the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst furnished the highest conversion of 85.2% with over 98% selectivity to ethanol. Similarly, the catalytic performance of the Cu9-Al0.5-Ca y catalysts increased with Ca amount y firstly and then decreased instead. However, the optimal molar ratio of Cu/Al/Ca was 9/0.5/0.5. Correspondingly, the Cu9-Al0.5-Ca0.5 gave slightly higher conversion of 72.8%. Nevertheless, compared with that of Mg, the improvement effect of Ca was very limited. Unfortunately, when doped with Ba or Sr, the conversion of ethyl acetate was dramatically decreased with Ba or Sr addition on Cu9-Al0.5-Ba y or Cu9-Al0.5-Sr y . Particularly, the drop tendency by the Cu9-Al0.5-Sr y catalysts was much stronger than that on the Cu9-Al0.5-Ba y catalysts. In order to understand these behaviors, the Cu9-Al0.5-M y catalysts were characterized using wide angle XRD, H2-TPR and N2 sorption. Fig. 4 shows the XRD patterns of Cu9-Al0.5-M y catalysts. For the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg y series (Fig. 4A), the diffraction peak of Cu became weaker once after Mg doped with low content (y =0.5). However, Cu diffraction strengthened with further increase of Mg amount. When the Mg amount reached at y =2.0, the Cu diffraction became extraordinary sharp. This indicates that too much Mg is not helpful for dispersion of Cu particles. According to Scherrer equation, the average Cu crystallite size was about 18nm of Cu9-Al0.5-Mg y (y =0.5, 1, 1.5), whereas the Cu crystallite size was about 26nm of Cu9-Al0.5-Mg2. With regards of Cu9-Al0.5-Ca y catalysts, CaCO3 was formed with Ca addition, as clearly shown in Fig. 4B. Similarly, the XRD patterns of the Cu9-Al0.5-Ba y catalysts and Cu9-Al0.5-Sr y catalysts also confirmed that the related carbonates were formed after Ba or Sr was doped to Cu9-Al0.5 catalysts (Fig. 4C and D). Correspondingly, the active sites could be covered by carbonates, resulting in rather low catalytic performance in comparison with that of the Cu-Al-Mg catalysts. The Cu9-Al0.5-M y catalysts were also characterized using nitrogen sorption. As shown in Fig. 5 , all Cu9-Al0.5-M1.5 catalysts displayed type IV isotherms with hysteresis loops at the medium relative pressure. Obviously, the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalysts had relatively higher specific surface area compared with Cu9-Al0.5 and other Cu9-Al0.5-M1.5 catalysts. For clarity, Table 1 lists the detailed physicochemical parameters of catalysts. After Mg was doped to Cu9-Al0.5 catalyst with optimal amount (y =1.5), the specific surface area of the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst was obviously increased from 72.2m2/g for Cu9-Al0.5 to 110.3m2/g. However, for Ca, Ba or Sr doped Cu9-Al0.5-M1.5 catalyst, the specific surface area was decreased instead compared with Cu9-Al0.5 binary catalyst. To understand the interaction of Cu-Al with the third component, the Cu9-Al0.5-M1.5 catalyst precursors after calcined in air at 350°C for 2h were further characterized by H2-TPR (Fig. 6 ). For all the samples, broad hydrogen uptake peak was observed, suggesting that there were many copper oxide species with different crystallite sizes or with variable interaction with Al or/and the third metal. For the binary Cu9-Al0.5 catalyst precursor, the H2 uptake initiated from 140°C and ended at about 390°C, assignable to reduction of CuO to Cu+ or to Cu0 [23]. With the third component doped, the reduction temperature for the Cu9-Al0.5-M1.5 catalyst precursors shifted to lower temperature. The reduction of the Cu-Al-M ternary catalyst precursors commenced from 120°C. However, for different alkaline-earth metal doped Cu9-Al0.5-M1.5 catalyst precursors, the reduction finished at different temperatures. The reduction for the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst precursor ended at about 370°C, while other Cu9-Al0.5-M1.5 catalyst precursors deceased the reduction at about 340–360°C. With the third component doped, the CuO in the Cu-Al-M catalyst precursor can be easily reduced to Cu2O or to Cu0 compared with that in Cu-Al binary system. That is, the reduction of CuO can be promoted after addition of alkaline-earth metal to Cu9-Al0.5 catalyst. Besides, the reduction extent for different Cu9-Al0.5-M1.5 catalysts was also calculated according to the hydrogen uptake amount. As also shown in Fig. 6, all the samples were almost fully reduced and the reduction extent was higher than 80%. Based on the systematic studies on the Cu-based catalysts in literatures, the balanced Cu+/Cu0 proportion is considered as the key factor for the polarization of CO bond and the activation of H2 [24,25]. Therefore, the oxidation states of copper in the Cu9-Al0.5, Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 and Cu9-Al0.5-Ca1.5 catalysts were probed with X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy after performing in-situ pre-treatment in a hydrogen flow at 350°C for 2h. The Cu2p XPS spectra for different Cu9-Al0.5-M1.5 catalysts are displayed in Fig. 7 A. For the binary Cu9-Al0.5 catalyst, the Cu2p 3/2 was centered at 932.5eV while the Cu2p 1/2 was centered as 952.4eV, characteristic of Cu0 or Cu+ species. The satellite peak at around 945–950eV is hardly observed, demonstrating that the Cu2+ species on the Cu9-Al0.5 catalyst surface is negligible. For Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 and Cu9-Al0.5-Ca1.5 catalysts, Cu0 or Cu+ species are also dominant on the catalyst surface besides a little Cu2+ species due to quite weak satellite peak at 945–950eV. As the binding energy for Cu0 and Cu+ species is too close to distinguish, the Cu LMM Auger electron spectroscopy was adopted. Fig. 7B shows the deconvoluted Cu LMM spectra for Cu9-Al0.5, Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 and Cu9-Al0.5-Ca1.5 catalysts. All the spectra were deconvoluted to four peaks using Lorenz/Gaussian of 1/99 [2,17,26–30]. The peaks at 565.6±0.3eV and 567.8±0.1eV are assigned to Cu0 species, while the peak at 569.9±0.1eV is attributed to Cu+ species. Due to overlapping of Cu0 and Cu+ peaks at around 570–574eV, we calculated the Cu0/(Cu0 +Cu+) just according to peak intensity at 565.6±0.3eV, 567.8±0.1eV and 569.9±0.1eV. As already attached in Fig. 7B, the Cu9-Al0.5, Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 and Cu9-Al0.5-Ca1.5 catalysts had Cu0/(Cu0 +Cu+) values of 62.4%, 51.5% and 67.1%, respectively. On recalling the catalytic test of Cu-Al or Cu-Al-M catalysts for the hydrogenation of ethyl acetate to ethanol, the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst was the most active among the three catalysts characterized by in-situ XPS. Therefore, we can conclude that the superior performance of the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst was attributed to the optimal Cu0/(Cu0 +Cu+) proportion. The Cu9-Al0.5 and Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalysts were also characterized by TEM and HRTEM (Fig. 8 ). Compared with Cu9-Al0.5 binary catalyst, the ternary Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst showed more uniform Cu particle dispersion and less aggregation. According to the HRTEM images in Fig. 8C and D, the Cu crystallite size is about 14nm for the Cu9-Al0.5 catalyst, while the Cu crystallite size is about 11nm for the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst. It is confirmed again that doping of Mg to Cu-Al binary catalyst, sintering of Cu particle was effectively prevented due to the interaction of Cu-Mg. Consequently, highly dispersed Cu particles having relatively higher specific surface area and the optimal Cu0/(Cu0 +Cu+) proportion determined that the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst behaved much better in the hydrogenation of ethyl acetate to ethanol. 3.3 Optimization of calcination temperature for Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst precursor Based on the results obtained above, we found that the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalysts were the most active catalyst for the hydrogenation of ethyl acetate. To further increase the catalytic performance of Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst, the calcination temperature for Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst precursor was optimized in the range of 250°C to 650°C. As can be seen in Fig. 9 A, with increase of the calcination temperature, the conversion of ethyl acetate was increased in the beginning and then decreased rapidly. As a result, the catalyst after calcined at 300–350°C showed the best performance. When combined with the XRD patterns of the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalysts after calcined at different temperatures (Fig. 9B), we found that the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst, after calcined in air at 300°C and then reduced in flowing hydrogen at 350°C, showed slightly weaker Cu0 diffraction. With increase of calcination temperature, the Cu particles were gathered to form large aggregations, which can be confirmed by the average crystallite size calculated according to the Scherrer equation. The average Cu crystallite size decreased firstly and then increased with the calcination temperature. Therefore, the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst after calcined at 300°C showed the highest activity and afforded about 90% conversion of ethyl acetate under the same conditions when compared with those calcined at other temperatures. To further interpret the superior performance of the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst after calcined at 300°C, the in-situ XPS was applied as well. As already displayed in Fig. 7A, the Cu0 or Cu+ species are dominant on the catalyst surface according to Cu2p XPS spectrum. In addition, the deconvoluted Cu LMM (Fig. 7B) for this catalyst also gave the Cu0/(Cu0 +Cu+) proportion of 52.4%, slightly higher than that for the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst after calcined at 350°C, but lower than those for Cu9-Al0.5 and Cu9-Al0.5-Ca1.5 catalyst. This implies that calcination in air for the catalyst precursor can modulate the Cu0/(Cu0 +Cu+) proportion on the catalyst surface. Furthermore, the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst after calcined at 300°C was also characterized using nitrogen sorption (Fig. 5B). As already listed in Table 1, the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst after calcined at 300°C had slightly higher specific surface area of 111.4m2/g compared with that for the one after calcined at 350°C. Consequently, the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst after calcined at 300°C was chosen as the standard catalyst for optimization of reaction conditions. 3.4 Optimization of reaction conditions To investigate the effect of reaction temperature on the catalytic activity, the ethyl acetate hydrogenation was carried out at different temperatures ranging from 200°C to 350°C. Fig. 10 exhibits the conversion of ethyl acetate versus reaction temperature plot. Apparently, the conversion of ethyl acetate is greatly influenced by the reaction temperature. The conversion of ethyl acetate was dramatically increased from 9.1% to 89.4% when the reaction temperature was increased from 200°C to 250°C. Of particular note is that the selectivity to ethanol could be kept unchanged. However, when the reaction temperature was further increased, the conversion of ethyl acetate was declined. As well known, ethyl acetate hydrogenation is an exothermic reaction (ΔH=−28.5kJ/mol). According to Le Chatelier's principle, increasing reaction temperature is not helpful for its forward reaction. It is clear that ethanol is the thermodynamically favored product at comparatively lower temperatures. Furthermore, reaction temperature of over 300°C may cause a series of side reactions [31,32]. The flow rate of hydrogen and ethyl acetate was also optimized in detail. As displayed in Fig. 11 A, when hydrogen flow was increased from 40ml/min to 60ml/min, the conversion of ethyl acetate was increased from 70.6% to 89.4%. Further increase of hydrogen flow rate cannot increase the conversion of ethyl acetate further. As for the ethyl acetate flow rate, the conversion was obviously decreased when ethyl acetate flow rate was increased due to shorter contact time (Fig. 11B). Hydrogen is used as a reactant in the reaction, so the hydrogen pressure might have a great impact on the catalytic performance. As shown in the inset of Fig. 11A, when the hydrogen pressure was increased from 1.5 to 2.0MPa, there was a big improvement in the conversion of ethyl acetate, with an increase from 71.3% to 89.4%. When the hydrogen pressure was further increased, the conversion of ethyl acetate was increased steadily. Furthermore, we calculated the reaction order versus hydrogen according to the results obtained under different hydrogen pressure. As a result, the hydrogenation of ethyl acetate versus hydrogen was the first order reaction. In addition, we also optimized the reduction temperature for the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst precursor. Fig. 12 shows the conversions of ethyl acetate afforded by the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst reduced in the range of 300–450°C. Remarkably, the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst after reduced at 350°C showed the striking catalytic performance by comparison with those reduced at other temperatures. To determine the onsite reduction of the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst, we performed the H2-TPR experiment for the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst, which has been reduced in flowing hydrogen at 350°C for 2h in the TPR apparatus to guarantee no further exposure to air. Consequently, extremely weak hydrogen uptake peak was detected. When compared with the hydrogen consumption for the calcined Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst precursor, the hydrogen consumption for the reduced Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst is only about 1.6% of that for the calcined one, indicating that the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst precursor can be reduced to Cu0 or Cu+ to a great extent at 350°C before submitted to hydrogenation reaction. 3.5 Catalyst life The catalyst life is often investigated to evaluate the stability of the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 13 , 93.9% of ethyl acetate conversion was achieved with the fresh Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst. With the reaction going, the conversion of ethyl acetate was gradually increased to 98%, and the selectivity to ethanol of over 98% can be kept almost constant. Within 210h test, the conversion of ethyl acetate did not decrease, indicating that the catalyst had excellent stability. After the life test, the used catalyst was characterized using TG and no coke was formed on the catalyst surface under the tested conditions. 4 Conclusions The Cu-based binary Cu-Al and ternary Cu-Al-M catalysts were applied for the hydrogenation of ethyl acetate to ethanol in a fixed-bed reactor. After screening different alkaline-earth metal component, Cu-Al-Mg ternary catalyst was found to be most active for the tested reaction. Correspondingly, Cu-Al-Mg molar ratio, calcination temperature, reaction temperature, reduction temperature, hydrogen flow rate and pressure and ethyl acetate flow rate were optimized in detail. Over 98% ethyl acetate conversion and ethanol selectivity were achieved on the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst under the optimized reaction conditions. The Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst also showed excellent stability as the activity and selectivity did not decrease during 210h life test. Based on the detailed characterizations using XRD, H2-TPR, TEM and XPS, the optimal Cu0/(Cu0 +Cu+) proportion on the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst surface, together with high specific surface area and relatively smaller Cu crystallite size, play key roles in superior performance of the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Cu9-Al x or Cu9-Al x -M y (M=Mg, Ca, Ba or Sr) catalysts were prepared by a deposition-precipitation method, characterized by means of H2-TPR, XRD and N2 sorption, and applied for hydrogenation of ethyl acetate to ethanol in a fixed-bed reactor. The molar ratio of Cu/Al or Cu/Al/M and the reaction parameters were investigated thoroughly. As a result, the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst with higher specific surface area, lower initial reduction temperature and better metal dispersion furnished 97.8% ethyl acetate conversion with 98% selectivity to ethanol under optimal reaction conditions. Moreover, the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst also showed good lifetime and neither the activity nor selectivity decreased during 210h test. Based on the characterization of the Cu9-Al0.5-Mg1.5 catalyst, the optimal Cu+/Cu0 proportion played a key role in determining the superior performance.
coredata.dc:title: Cu9-Al x -Mg y catalysts for hydrogenation of ethyl acetate to ethanol
